questions.stem: The landmark case Dusky v. United States (1960) established the legal standard for which of the following forensic psychology evaluations?

options.text: Insanity at the time of the offense
Competency to stand trial
Involuntary civil commitment
Fitness for duty in law enforcement

questions.explanation: Dusky v. United States (1960) established the standard for competency to stand trial (CST), which is the most frequently raised forensic psychology issue in criminal proceedings. The Dusky standard requires that a defendant have: (1) a rational understanding of the charges, (2) a factual understanding of the proceedings, and (3) the ability to consult with their attorney with a reasonable degree of rational understanding. CST is a present-state evaluation, not a retrospective assessment.

questions.stem: Which insanity defense standard includes BOTH a cognitive prong (ability to appreciate wrongfulness) AND a volitional prong (ability to conform conduct to the law)?

options.text: M'Naghten Rule
Durham Rule (Product Test)
ALI/Model Penal Code Standard
Insanity Defense Reform Act (IDRA)

questions.explanation: The ALI/Model Penal Code standard (1962) is the only insanity defense standard that includes both a cognitive prong (lacked substantial capacity to appreciate the wrongfulness of conduct) and a volitional prong (lacked substantial capacity to conform conduct to the requirements of the law). M'Naghten includes only a cognitive test. The Durham Rule uses a broad 'product of mental disease' test. The IDRA (1984) eliminated the volitional prong from the federal standard after the Hinckley acquittal.

questions.stem: Tarasoff II (1976) expanded the mental health professional's obligation from a 'duty to warn' to a broader 'duty to protect.' Which of the following BEST describes the expanded duty under Tarasoff II?

options.text: The therapist must warn all potential victims regardless of identifiability
The therapist must take reasonable steps to protect the potential victim, which may include but is not limited to warning
The therapist must involuntarily hospitalize any client who makes a threat
The therapist must report all threats to law enforcement within 24 hours

questions.explanation: Tarasoff I (1974) established a duty to warn the identified potential victim. Tarasoff II (1976) broadened this to a duty to protect, meaning the therapist must take reasonable steps to protect the potential victim. These steps may include warning the victim, notifying police, adjusting treatment (e.g., voluntary or involuntary hospitalization), or other interventions. The duty is triggered when the therapist determines (or should have determined) that the client poses a serious threat to a reasonably identifiable victim.

questions.stem: Under the Daubert standard for admissibility of expert testimony, which of the following is NOT one of the four factors the trial judge must consider?

options.text: Whether the theory or technique has been tested
Whether the theory has been subjected to peer review and publication
Whether the expert has at least 10 years of clinical experience
Whether the theory is generally accepted in the relevant scientific community

questions.explanation: The Daubert standard (1993) identifies four factors for admissibility of expert testimony: (1) testability, (2) peer review and publication, (3) known error rate, and (4) general acceptance in the relevant scientific community. Years of clinical experience is not one of the Daubert factors. The trial judge serves as 'gatekeeper' to evaluate whether testimony is based on reliable scientific methodology. Kumho Tire (1999) later extended this gatekeeping function to all expert testimony, not just scientific testimony.

questions.stem: In Addington v. Texas (1979), the Supreme Court established that the standard of proof required for involuntary civil commitment must be at least:

options.text: Preponderance of the evidence
Clear and convincing evidence
Beyond a reasonable doubt
Probable cause

questions.explanation: Addington v. Texas (1979) established that the standard of proof for civil commitment must be at least 'clear and convincing evidence.' This standard is higher than the civil 'preponderance of the evidence' standard but lower than the criminal 'beyond a reasonable doubt' standard. The Court recognized that civil commitment involves a significant deprivation of liberty and therefore requires a higher evidentiary threshold than ordinary civil proceedings.

questions.stem: Select ALL components of the Dusky standard for competency to stand trial.

options.text: A rational understanding of the charges and proceedings
A factual understanding of the charges and proceedings
The ability to consult with an attorney with a reasonable degree of rational understanding
The ability to appreciate the wrongfulness of the alleged criminal act at the time it occurred
A retrospective assessment of the defendant's mental state at the time of the offense

questions.explanation: The Dusky standard requires three elements: (1) rational understanding of charges and proceedings, (2) factual understanding of charges and proceedings, and (3) ability to consult with counsel with a reasonable degree of rational understanding. The ability to appreciate wrongfulness pertains to insanity defense standards (ALI/IDRA), not competency. Similarly, retrospective assessment is relevant to insanity evaluations. Competency is a present-state evaluation assessing the defendant's current ability to participate in their defense.

questions.stem: Select ALL recognized exceptions to psychotherapist-patient privilege in legal proceedings.

options.text: When the client poses an imminent danger to self or others
Mandatory reporting of suspected child abuse or neglect
When the client raises their mental health as an issue in litigation
When a family member requests the client's records
Court-ordered evaluations where the relationship is not therapeutic

questions.explanation: Recognized exceptions to psychotherapist-patient privilege include: danger to self or others (consistent with Tarasoff duties), mandatory child abuse reporting, when the client raises mental health in litigation (waiving privilege), court-ordered evaluations (no therapeutic relationship exists), and malpractice claims (therapist may disclose in self-defense). A family member's request does not constitute a valid exception to privilege. Privilege belongs to the client and can only be waived by the client.

questions.stem: According to Sell v. United States (2003), select ALL criteria that must be met for involuntary medication of an incompetent defendant solely for the purpose of competency restoration.

options.text: An important governmental interest is at stake
Medication is substantially likely to render the defendant competent
Medication is substantially unlikely to have side effects that interfere with the defendant's ability to assist counsel
The defendant has a prior history of violent behavior
No less intrusive alternative treatment exists

questions.explanation: Sell v. United States (2003) established four criteria for involuntary medication to restore competency: (1) important governmental interest at stake, (2) medication substantially likely to render defendant competent, (3) medication substantially unlikely to produce side effects interfering with the defendant's ability to assist counsel, and (4) no less intrusive alternative exists. A history of violent behavior is not among the Sell criteria. The ruling balances the government's interest in prosecution against the defendant's liberty interest in refusing medication.

questions.stem: Select ALL statements that accurately describe the PCL-R (Hare Psychopathy Checklist-Revised).

options.text: It is a 20-item clinician-rated scale
Factor 1 assesses interpersonal and affective traits such as grandiosity and lack of empathy
The cutoff score for a psychopathy designation is 30
It is a self-report measure completed by the examinee
It is a robust predictor of violent recidivism

questions.explanation: The PCL-R is a 20-item clinician-rated (not self-report) scale with a cutoff score of 30 for psychopathy designation. It has two factors: Factor 1 (interpersonal/affective: grandiosity, callousness, lack of empathy) and Factor 2 (social deviance: impulsivity, irresponsibility, criminal versatility). The PCL-R is well-established as a robust predictor of violent recidivism and is widely used in forensic risk assessments.

questions.stem: Select ALL statements that accurately describe the distinction between competency to stand trial and the insanity defense.

options.text: Competency is a present-state evaluation; insanity is a retrospective evaluation
Competency asks whether the defendant can participate in their defense; insanity asks whether the defendant was mentally responsible at the time of the offense
Both competency and insanity are assessed at the time of the offense
Competency is the most frequently raised forensic issue in criminal proceedings
The insanity defense is raised in less than 1% of felony cases

questions.explanation: Competency and insanity are distinct legal concepts. Competency is a present-state evaluation of whether the defendant can currently participate in their defense (understanding charges, consulting with attorney). Insanity is a retrospective evaluation of the defendant's mental state at the time of the offense. Competency is the most frequently raised forensic issue. The insanity defense is raised in less than 1% of felony cases and is successful in approximately 25% of those cases, mostly through plea bargains rather than jury trials.

questions.stem: Match each insanity defense standard with its key defining criterion.

columns.text: Cognitive test only: did not know nature/quality of act or that it was wrong
Broadest: act was the product of mental disease or defect
Includes both cognitive (appreciate) and volitional (conform) prongs
Federal standard post-Hinckley: eliminated volitional prong, burden on defense

questions.explanation: M'Naghten (1843) is a purely cognitive test -- the defendant did not know the nature and quality of the act or did not know it was wrong. Durham (1954) is the broadest standard, requiring only that the act was the 'product of' mental disease (largely abandoned due to vagueness). ALI/MPC (1962) uniquely includes both cognitive and volitional prongs. IDRA (1984) was enacted after Hinckley's acquittal and eliminated the volitional prong from the federal standard, shifted the burden to the defense, and required clear and convincing evidence.

questions.stem: Match each landmark case with the legal principle it established.

columns.text: Non-dangerous mentally ill persons cannot be involuntarily confined
Incompetent defendants cannot be held indefinitely for restoration
Daubert gatekeeping extended to all expert testimony, not just scientific

questions.explanation: Jaffee v. Redmond (1996) established psychotherapist-patient privilege in federal courts, including communications with licensed social workers. O'Connor v. Donaldson (1975) held that a non-dangerous, mentally ill person who can survive safely in freedom cannot be involuntarily confined. Jackson v. Indiana (1972) established that defendants cannot be held indefinitely for competency restoration. Kumho Tire v. Carmichael (1999) extended the Daubert gatekeeping function to all expert testimony, including clinical and technical opinions.

questions.stem: For each risk assessment approach, select ALL characteristics that correctly describe it.

columns.text: Uses fixed algorithm with no clinical override
Allows clinical judgment in final determination

questions.explanation: The PCL-R primarily assesses personality traits (static factors), though it informs risk assessment. The VRAG is a purely actuarial instrument using fixed algorithms with 12 static risk factors and no clinical override. The HCR-20 is a structured professional judgment (SPJ) tool that includes Historical (static), Clinical (dynamic), and Risk Management (contextual) domains and allows clinical judgment. Unstructured clinical judgment allows clinical judgment but lacks the structure of validated tools. Research shows actuarial tools and SPJ outperform unstructured judgment.

questions.stem: For each civil commitment landmark case, select ALL legal principles it established.

columns.text: Standard of proof must be clear and convincing evidence
Right to treatment in least restrictive environment
Rights to safety, freedom from restraint, and minimally adequate training
Mental illness alone is insufficient for involuntary confinement

questions.explanation: Addington v. Texas established the 'clear and convincing evidence' standard for civil commitment. Wyatt v. Stickney established the right to treatment in the least restrictive environment for involuntarily committed individuals. Youngberg v. Romeo established constitutional rights to safety, freedom from unnecessary restraint, and minimally adequate training/habilitation. O'Connor v. Donaldson held that a non-dangerous mentally ill person who can survive safely in freedom cannot be involuntarily confined -- mental illness alone is insufficient.

questions.stem: Under the Daubert standard, the trial judge serves as {{blank1}} to evaluate expert testimony. The four factors include testability, peer review, {{blank2}}, and general acceptance. The older {{blank3}} standard required only general acceptance in the relevant scientific community. {{blank4}} extended Daubert gatekeeping to all expert testimony, not just scientific testimony.

options.text: gatekeeper
advocate
mediator
fact-finder
years of expert experience
known error rate
number of publications
professional licensure status
Daubert
Kumho Tire
Frye
Tarasoff
Frye v. United States
Kumho Tire v. Carmichael
Jaffee v. Redmond
Daubert v. Merrell Dow

questions.explanation: Under Daubert (1993), the trial judge serves as 'gatekeeper' evaluating expert testimony on four factors: testability, peer review/publication, known error rate, and general acceptance. The older Frye standard (1923) required only general acceptance. Kumho Tire v. Carmichael (1999) extended Daubert's gatekeeping function to all expert testimony, including clinical and technical opinions, not just scientific testimony. This is particularly important for forensic psychologists whose clinical opinions must meet reliability standards.

questions.stem: Civil commitment typically requires two elements: the individual has a {{blank1}} and, as a result, is a {{blank2}} or is gravely disabled. The constitutional basis for committing individuals who are dangerous to others is the state's {{blank3}} power, while committing those who cannot care for themselves relies on the {{blank4}} doctrine.

options.text: mental illness
criminal history
substance use disorder only
personality disorder diagnosis
financial burden to the community
danger to self or others
noncompliant with treatment
socially isolated
parens patriae
police
executive
legislative
police power
due process
parens patriae
habeas corpus

questions.explanation: Civil commitment requires: (1) a mental illness and (2) dangerousness to self/others or grave disability. Two constitutional bases support involuntary state action: Police power authorizes the state to protect public safety (committing those dangerous to others). Parens patriae ('parent of the country') authorizes the state to protect those who cannot protect themselves (gravely disabled individuals). These two doctrines represent distinct but sometimes overlapping justifications for civil commitment.

questions.stem: A forensic psychologist is asked to evaluate a defendant's competency to stand trial. The defendant, diagnosed with chronic paranoid schizophrenia, believes the judge is part of a conspiracy against him and refuses to cooperate with his defense attorney, stating that the attorney is 'working for them.' He can correctly name the charges against him and identifies the roles of the judge, prosecutor, and jury.

options.text: Factual understanding of charges is preserved but rational understanding is compromised by paranoid delusions
Ability to consult with attorney is impaired by delusional beliefs about the attorney's loyalty
All three Dusky prongs are fully intact despite the diagnosis
The defendant's refusal to cooperate reflects a rational legal strategy
Incompetent to stand trial, as the defendant lacks rational understanding and ability to consult with counsel
Competent to stand trial because factual understanding is preserved
Not guilty by reason of insanity based on the current paranoid symptoms
Recommend competency restoration treatment, likely including antipsychotic medication and psychoeducation
Advise the court that the defendant requires treatment before proceeding to trial
Recommend immediate sentencing since the defendant acknowledges the charges
Conduct an insanity evaluation instead since the defendant has a psychotic disorder

questions.explanation: The defendant demonstrates factual understanding (can name charges and courtroom roles) but lacks rational understanding (paranoid beliefs about the judge's conspiracy) and impaired ability to consult with counsel (believes attorney is part of the conspiracy). Under Dusky, all three prongs must be met. The most likely determination is incompetent to stand trial. Appropriate next steps include recommending competency restoration (psychoeducation and medication). Approximately 70-80% of defendants are successfully restored within 6 months. Competency is a present-state evaluation; insanity is a separate, retrospective question.

questions.stem: A psychologist conducting a violence risk assessment evaluates a 28-year-old male with a history of domestic violence, active methamphetamine use, antisocial personality traits (PCL-R score of 26), and recent loss of employment. He has expressed homicidal ideation toward his ex-partner but denies having a specific plan.

options.text: Active substance use (dynamic risk factor that can be targeted for intervention)
History of domestic violence (static risk factor increasing baseline risk)
PCL-R score below the psychopathy cutoff but elevated antisocial traits
No identifiable risk factors given the absence of a specific plan
Structured professional judgment integrating both static and dynamic risk factors
Unstructured clinical impression based on interview alone
Risk assessment is unnecessary because the PCL-R score is below cutoff
Substance abuse treatment as a primary dynamic risk factor intervention
Consider Tarasoff duty to protect given the identifiable potential victim
Discharge from treatment since the client does not meet the PCL-R cutoff for psychopathy
No intervention needed because the threat lacks a specific plan

questions.explanation: Multiple risk factors are present: active substance use (a dynamic/modifiable risk factor), history of domestic violence (a static risk factor), employment instability, and homicidal ideation toward an identifiable victim. Note that the PCL-R score of 26 is below the clinical cutoff of 30 but is not listed as a correct risk factor in this framing because the distractor incorrectly states it is 'below cutoff' as if that negates risk. Best practice uses structured professional judgment integrating both static and dynamic factors. Appropriate recommendations include substance abuse treatment (targeting the dynamic risk) and considering Tarasoff duty to protect the identified ex-partner.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe forensic psychology concepts and legal standards.
questions.passage: Forensic psychology involves the intersection of psychology and law. [Competency to stand trial is a present-state evaluation, while the insanity defense requires a retrospective assessment of mental state at the time of the offense]. [The M'Naghten Rule is the broadest insanity standard because it includes both cognitive and volitional prongs]. [Jaffee v. Redmond established psychotherapist-patient privilege in federal courts, including communications with licensed social workers]. [Under Jones v. United States, NGRI acquittees may be confined in a psychiatric hospital for longer than the maximum prison sentence for the crime]. [The Frye standard is more flexible than Daubert because it considers multiple factors including testability and error rate]. [GBMI (Guilty But Mentally Ill) is a verdict that acknowledges mental illness but does not reduce the defendant's sentence].

highlightableSegments.text: Competency to stand trial is a present-state evaluation, while the insanity defense requires a retrospective assessment of mental state at the time of the offense
The M'Naghten Rule is the broadest insanity standard because it includes both cognitive and volitional prongs
Jaffee v. Redmond established psychotherapist-patient privilege in federal courts, including communications with licensed social workers
Under Jones v. United States, NGRI acquittees may be confined in a psychiatric hospital for longer than the maximum prison sentence for the crime
The Frye standard is more flexible than Daubert because it considers multiple factors including testability and error rate
GBMI (Guilty But Mentally Ill) is a verdict that acknowledges mental illness but does not reduce the defendant's sentence

questions.explanation: Segment 1 is correct: CST is present-state; insanity is retrospective. Segment 2 is incorrect: M'Naghten is the most restrictive standard (cognitive test only); the ALI standard includes both prongs. The Durham rule is the broadest. Segment 3 is correct: Jaffee established federal privilege including for social workers. Segment 4 is correct: Jones held NGRI commitment can exceed the maximum sentence. Segment 5 is incorrect: Frye uses only general acceptance; Daubert is more flexible with multiple factors. Segment 6 is correct: GBMI does not reduce the sentence.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe violence risk assessment principles.
questions.passage: Violence risk assessment is a critical forensic psychology function. [Static risk factors are historical and unchangeable, such as age at first offense and prior convictions]. [Dynamic risk factors are modifiable criminogenic needs that can be targeted for intervention, such as substance use and antisocial attitudes]. [Actuarial risk assessment tools consistently outperform unstructured clinical judgment in predicting violence]. [Structured professional judgment tools like the HCR-20 produce less accurate predictions than purely actuarial instruments]. [Even highly accurate risk assessment tools can produce many false positives when the base rate of violence in the population is low]. [The fourth generation of risk assessment integrates risk, needs, and management planning rather than focusing solely on prediction].

highlightableSegments.text: Static risk factors are historical and unchangeable, such as age at first offense and prior convictions
Dynamic risk factors are modifiable criminogenic needs that can be targeted for intervention, such as substance use and antisocial attitudes
Actuarial risk assessment tools consistently outperform unstructured clinical judgment in predicting violence
Structured professional judgment tools like the HCR-20 produce less accurate predictions than purely actuarial instruments
Even highly accurate risk assessment tools can produce many false positives when the base rate of violence in the population is low
The fourth generation of risk assessment integrates risk, needs, and management planning rather than focusing solely on prediction

questions.explanation: Segments 1, 2, 3, 5, and 6 are correct. Static factors are historical/unchangeable; dynamic factors are modifiable. Actuarial tools do outperform unstructured judgment. Base rate issues affect predictive accuracy (even accurate tests yield false positives with low base rates). Fourth-generation tools (e.g., START) integrate risk/needs/management. Segment 4 is incorrect: research shows SPJ approaches (like the HCR-20) perform comparably to actuarial methods, not worse. SPJ allows clinical judgment while maintaining structure.

questions.stem: Arrange the following insanity defense standards in chronological order from earliest to most recent.

items.text: M'Naghten Rule -- cognitive test only (nature/quality or knowledge of wrong)
Durham Rule -- act was the 'product of' mental disease or defect
ALI/Model Penal Code -- cognitive (appreciate) and volitional (conform) prongs
Insanity Defense Reform Act -- eliminated volitional prong, burden on defense
Kansas v. Hendricks -- upheld sexually violent predator civil commitment laws
Ake v. Oklahoma -- indigent defendants' right to psychiatric expert when sanity is at issue

questions.explanation: The chronological order is: M'Naghten Rule (1843), Durham Rule (1954), ALI/Model Penal Code (1962), IDRA (1984), Ake v. Oklahoma (1985), and Kansas v. Hendricks (1997). Note: Ake (1985) was decided after the IDRA (1984), and Kansas v. Hendricks (1997) came later. The IDRA was passed after John Hinckley Jr.'s acquittal and tightened the federal insanity standard by eliminating the volitional prong and shifting the burden of proof to the defense.

questions.stem: Arrange the following risk assessment approaches in order from the first generation to the fourth generation.

items.text: Unstructured clinical judgment -- clinician's subjective impression without systematic tools
Actuarial instruments (e.g., VRAG) -- algorithmic scoring using static risk factors
Structured professional judgment (e.g., HCR-20) -- systematic framework allowing clinical judgment
Integration of risk/needs with management planning (e.g., START) -- combines assessment with intervention
Machine learning models incorporating real-time behavioral data
Ongoing dynamic risk monitoring integrated into treatment planning

questions.explanation: Risk assessment has evolved through generations: First generation = unstructured clinical judgment (least accurate). Second generation = actuarial instruments like the VRAG that use fixed algorithms with static factors. Third generation = structured professional judgment (SPJ) tools like the HCR-20 that incorporate dynamic factors and clinical judgment. Fourth generation = integration of risk, needs, and management planning (e.g., START). Emerging approaches include machine learning and continuous dynamic monitoring. Each generation has built upon the limitations of the previous one.

questions.stem: A forensic researcher tracks competency restoration outcomes for defendants with different diagnoses over a 12-month treatment period. The data show the percentage of defendants in each diagnostic group who are successfully restored to competency at each assessment point.
questions.question: What conclusion is best supported by these data regarding competency restoration?

options.text: Intellectual disability has the same restoration rates as acute psychosis when given adequate time
Defendants with medication-responsive psychosis show substantially higher restoration rates than those with intellectual disability, consistent with research on restoration failure predictors
Both groups achieve full competency restoration by 12 months
Competency restoration is equally effective across all diagnostic groups when standardized protocols are used

questions.explanation: The data show that defendants with medication-responsive acute psychosis achieve high restoration rates (92% by 12 months), with the majority restored within 6 months. In contrast, defendants with intellectual disability show much lower restoration rates (only 22% by 12 months), with 78% never being restored. This is consistent with research indicating that intellectual disability, chronic treatment-resistant psychosis, and neurocognitive disorders are associated with failure to restore. Under Jackson v. Indiana, defendants who cannot be restored cannot be held indefinitely, and civil commitment proceedings may be initiated.

questions.stem: A researcher examines the accuracy of three violence risk prediction methods (unstructured clinical judgment, actuarial tool, and structured professional judgment) across varying base rates of violence in different populations. The data represent Area Under the Curve (AUC) values, where higher values indicate better discrimination.
questions.question: What pattern do these data support regarding violence risk assessment methods?

options.text: Unstructured clinical judgment is equivalent to structured methods across all base rates
Actuarial tools and structured professional judgment perform comparably and both substantially outperform unstructured clinical judgment
Structured professional judgment is consistently inferior to actuarial tools
Base rate has no effect on the accuracy of any risk assessment method

questions.explanation: The data show that actuarial tools (AUC 0.72-0.77) and structured professional judgment (AUC 0.70-0.76) perform comparably across base rates, both substantially outperforming unstructured clinical judgment (AUC 0.58-0.64). This is consistent with research showing that actuarial and SPJ approaches produce similar discrimination accuracy, while unstructured judgment is notably less accurate. All methods show slight improvement at higher base rates, reflecting the well-established principle that predictive accuracy is affected by base rates. The comparable performance of SPJ and actuarial tools supports the use of either structured approach.

questions.stem: Categorize each of the following forensic assessment instruments by its primary forensic purpose.

items.text: MacCAT-CA (MacArthur Competence Assessment Tool)
HCR-20 (Historical-Clinical-Risk Management)
PCL-R (Psychopathy Checklist-Revised)
VRAG (Violence Risk Appraisal Guide)
Competency Screening Test (CST)
Competency to Stand Trial Assessment Instrument (CAI)

questions.explanation: Competency assessment instruments include the MacCAT-CA (structured interview assessing Understanding, Reasoning, and Appreciation), the Competency Screening Test (22-item sentence completion screening), and the CAI (13 rated functions). Violence risk assessment instruments include the HCR-20 (SPJ tool with Historical, Clinical, and Risk Management domains) and the VRAG (actuarial tool with 12 static risk factors). The PCL-R is primarily a psychopathy assessment tool (20 items, two factors, cutoff of 30), though PCL-R scores also inform violence risk predictions.

questions.stem: Categorize each risk factor as either a static (historical/unchangeable) risk factor or a dynamic (modifiable/criminogenic need) risk factor.

items.text: Age at first criminal offense
Active substance use
Prior conviction history
Antisocial attitudes and peer associations
History of childhood abuse
Current employment instability

questions.explanation: Static risk factors are historical and unchangeable: age at first offense, prior convictions, and history of childhood abuse are all fixed aspects of a person's history. Dynamic risk factors (criminogenic needs) are modifiable targets for intervention: substance use can be treated, antisocial attitudes can be addressed through interventions like cognitive restructuring, and employment instability can be improved through vocational support. Effective risk management addresses dynamic factors while acknowledging the baseline risk indicated by static factors.
